Catalysts CO conversion, % HC selectivity, b wt.% C2-4 =/C2-4 CH4 C2-4 C5 + FeSi 18.6 18.1 36.3 45.7 0.44 LiFeSi 15.3 15.0 29.1 56.0 0.59 NaFeSi 18.4 5.3 17.7 77.0 0.77 KFeSi 34.4 3.8 15.1 81.1 0.75 RbFeSi 26.3 8.2 28.4 63.4 0.75 a Reaction conditions: H2/CO=2.0, 260°C, 1.5MPa, 2000h−1. b Hydrocarbon selectivities are reported on the basis of total hydrocarbon in weight. Effects of alkali on iron-based catalysts for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis: CO chemisorptions study Jifan Li a b c Xiaofan Cheng b Chenghua Zhang a b ⁎ Yong Yang a b Yongwang Li a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China b National Engineering Laboratory for Indirect Coal Liquefaction, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China National Engineering Laboratory for Indirect Coal Liquefaction, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China c Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 010 69667802. Graphical abstract The CO hydrogenation reactions over un-promoted and alkali (Li, Na, K and Rb) promoted iron-based catalysts were studied by pulsing CO method. The pulse experiments indicate that alkali metals suppress the CO hydrogenation or conversion and the methane formation. Through analyzing the data, it is found that alkali promoters decrease the surface concentration of hydrogen, improve the CO adsorption and increase the retention time of carbon species on the catalyst surface in the turn of Li, Na, K, Rb. These promotional effects well explain the hydrocarbon product variation over different alkali promoted catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Keywords Alkali promoters Fischer-Tropsch synthesis CO pulse experiments Methane formation 1 Introduction The increasing price of crude oil due to increased demand and the shrinkage of reserves has focused a great deal of attention on the use of coal and biomass as feedstocks for the production of synthetic liquid fuels via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) technology [1]. However, the formation of CH4 in FTS as byproduct wastes materials and energy, and has to be suppressed for economical reasons [2]. The control of CH4 selectivity becomes one of the key issues during FTS. In FTS reaction, methane is formed via the stepwise hydrogenation of surface carbon species (CH x , x =1 to 3) [3]. Previous studies have indicated that the competition between surface carbon hydrogenation and CC coupling is the key factor for methane and long-chain hydrocarbon selectivity [4,5]. So, the modification of the reactivity of surface carbon species towards hydrogen may be a valid method to control the methane production. It is well-known that potassium is the most effective chemical promoter for the suppression of methane over iron-based FTS catalysts. It was reported to inhibit the surface carbon hydrogenation and promote the carbon chain growth [6–9]. Other alkali metals (Li, Na, Rb) have similar chemical properties to potassium and some studies related to alkali effect on CO hydrogenation over iron-based or Mo2C nanoparticles have been reported [10–12]. However, investigation related to their effects on the hydrogenation of carbon species using transient techniques was rarely reported. The transient response technique is an effective method for the study of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface [13–17]. It involves a sudden change in the conditions of the heterogeneous catalytic reactions and records the response which monitored as a function of time. The resulting response contains valuable information on the kinetics and mechanism of the surface reactions. At the same time, the hydrogenation of CO to form methane has been proven already to be an ideal system for transient investigations due to the simple molecules involved, which is easy to trace by mass spectrometry [3,13,16,18]. In the past decades, transient techniques were successfully applied to investigate the hydrogenation of surface carbon species [4,8,15,16]. Two parallel pools of surface intermediates (CαH x and CβH x ) are proposed to react irreversibly to CH4 on the Rh/SiO2 catalyst [15]. Recently, the formation of methane on un-promoted and potassium-promoted iron catalysts was studied by pulsing CO in H2 flow method [19]. They concluded that potassium influence the formation of methane by blocking the fast formation channel and by establishing a new and slower reaction pathway. From these work, the surface carbon transient hydrogenation could be an effective method for the study of the chemical environments of catalyst surfaces. Moreover, the transient method that pulsing CO into a steady-state H2 flow is a simple but effectively transient response technique to characterize the surface coverages and residence time of carbon-containing species on the catalyst surface [15,19]. Simultaneously, some smaller alkanes also can be observed, which respond to surface carbon species coupling and chain growth [19]. Therefore, pulsing CO method would be a valid transient method to elucidate the promotional effects of alkali metals on the surface CO hydrogenation over iron based catalysts. In this study, the pulsing CO hydrogenation was employed to study effects of alkali metals on the reactivity of surface carbon towards hydrogen over FeSi catalysts. The purpose was to develop a better understanding of alkali metal promotional effects (Li, Na, K, and Rb) on FTS reaction of iron-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts used in present study were prepared by the combination of co-precipitation and spray-drying technology. In brief, a solution containing ferric nitrate and silica sol in the desired ratio (Si:Fe atomic ratio=5:100) was used in precipitation with NH4OH solution as precipitator at pH=8.5±0.3 and T =343K. The precipitate was washed, and then filtered. The alkali (Li, Na, K, and Rb) was subsequently added by wetness impregnation with an aqueous alkali nitrate to obtain an alkali/iron atomic ratio of 2:100. The mixture was re-slurried and spray-dried. The spray-dried powder was calcined at 773K for 5h in a muffle furnace. The catalysts were denoted FeSi, LiFeSi, NaFeSi, KFeSi, and RbFeSi. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 Physical adsorption The BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalysts as prepared were obtained via nitrogen physisorption in ASAP 2420 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). Each sample was degassed under vacuum at 90°C for 1h and 350°C for 8h prior to the measurement. 2.2.2 Catalyst composition The concentration of the metal in the catalyst was determined by an Induced Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES, Thermo Icap 6300, USA). 2.2.3 Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) The elemental concentrations of the catalyst surfaces and elemental distributions were studied using EDX. EDX was performed using an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). Before the EDS test, the grinded catalyst was pressed into a tablet. 2.2.4 Temperature programmed reduction in H2 (H2-TPR) H2-TPR studies were carried out with Autochem II 2920 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). A sample of 40mg of catalyst was loaded into a U-type quartz tube reactor and ramped from room temperature to 1073K in 10% H2/90% Ar with the heating rate of 10K/min and the flow rate of 50ml/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to monitor the variation of the outlet gas concentration. Isopropyl alcohol gel (185K) was used to remove water formed during the reduction. 2.2.5 Mössbauer spectra (MES) MES measurements were carried out in an MR-351 constant-acceleration Mössbauer spectrometer (FAST, Germany) drive with a triangular reference signal at room temperature. The radioactive source was 25-mCi57Co in a Pd matrix. Data analysis was performed using a nonlinear least-squares fitting routine that modeled the spectra as a combination of singlets, quadruple doublets, and magnetic sextets based on a Lorentzian lineshape profile. The components were identified based on their isomer shift (IS), quadruple splitting (QS), and magnetic hyperfine fields (Hhf). Magnetic hyperfine fields were calibrated with the 330 kOe field of α-Fe at the room temperature. The reduced catalyst samples used for MES characterization were prepared by reducing the fresh catalysts in a quartz tube with synthesis gas (H2/CO=2) at 553K, 0.10MPa, and 1000h−1 for 20h. After reduction, the catalysts for MES measurements were coated with paraffin to prevent oxidation. 2.3 Pulse experiments CO pulse experiments were carried out with Autochem II 2920 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). The flow set-up used for the pulse experiments consisted of a gas supply system including a dosing loop (V =500μL) for pulsing CO, a heated reactor and a calibrated quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar, Pfeiffer) for on-line gas analysis. About 100mg catalyst with a size range of 40-60 mesh was loaded into a U-type quartz tube reactor. Prior to pulse CO, the sample was reduced with pure H2 (50ml/min) at 723K for 5h. The catalyst was subsequently flushed at the same temperature with He (50ml/min) for 30min and cooled to 533K. After that, a pulse of 5% CO/95% He was introduced into a flow of pure H2. The concentrations of the hydrogenation products (CH4 and C2H6) as well as the concentration of CO were continuously analyzed using online calibrated quadrupole mass spectrometer. Two sets of additional pulse experiments were also performed over all the samples. The catalysts were pretreated in the same condition, but the pulse of 5% CO/95% He was introduced into a flow of 10% H2/90% He or pure He. The percent of CO conversion in this study was calculated based on the following equation: Conversion ( % ) = ( C O i n − C O o u t ) / C O i n × 100 where COin is the amount of CO injected in a pulse, and COout is the effluent amount of CO in the pulse. The effluent amounts of CH4 and C2H6 were calculated based on the integration of pulse peak areas. 2.4 Steady-state experiments The FTS performance of catalysts was tested in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with inner diameter of 12mm. About 3g catalyst was loaded into the isothermal region of reactor for all the reaction tests. The remaining volume of the reactor tube was filled with quartz granules in a size range of 40–60mesh. All the catalysts were activated with syngas (H2/CO=2.0) at 553K, 0.10MPa, and 1000h−1 for 20h. The reaction conditions were maintained at 533K, 1.5MPa, 2000h−1, and H2/CO=2.0. A detailed description of the reactor and the product analysis system has been provided elsewhere [20]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 BET surface area Table 1 gives the BET surface areas, pore volume and average pore size of the catalysts. Slightly lower BET surface areas (10–20%) but bigger average pore size was found for the catalysts with Li or Na promotion compared with the benchmark FeSi catalyst. Taking into account experimental error, the BET surface areas of the K and Rb promoted catalysts and FeSi catalysts were essentially identical. In addition, there is almost no apparent difference in the pore volume for these catalysts. 3.1.2 EDX EDX mapping was used to analyze the elemental distribution on the surface of the calcined catalyst particles. As seen in Fig. 1 , all elements are well distributed on the surface of the catalyst particles, with no obvious segregation. 3.1.3 Reduction behaviors of catalysts The reduction behaviors of catalysts were investigated by H2-TPR. The reduction profiles for catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . In the profile of FeSi catalyst, two well-separated H2 consumption peaks can be observed, which is characteristic of the two-step reduction of iron oxides from α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and Fe3O4 to α-Fe [20]. With the addition of alkali metals, the positions of these peaks shift to higher temperature. The temperature of the first reduction peak (i.e. the reduction peak from α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4) increases in the order of FeSi<LiFeSi<NaFeSi, and then slightly decreases with increasing the atomic number of the alkali metals. These results clearly indicate that the incorporation of alkali metals inhibit the reduction of catalysts. It may be due to the inhibiting effect of alkali metals on the H2 chemisorption adsorption [7]. The phase compositions of catalysts after pretreatment in syngas (H2/CO=2.0) at 553K for 20h are determined by MES. The Mössbauer spectra are shown in Fig. 3 . Table 2 lists the iron phase compositions of the samples obtained by fitting the Mössbauer spectra. The MES spectra of catalysts contain several sets of sextets. The sextets with Hhf of 485±1 kOe and 455±1 kOe can be attributed to the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of Fe3O4. Other sextets with Hhf of 213–228 kOe, 175–187 kOe and 110 kOe correspond to the three different sites of stoichiometric iron carbide (χ-Fe5C2) [7]. As shown in Table 2, the FeSi catalyst contains 12.9% iron carbide. The iron carbide contribution decreases with the addition of Li and Na, whereas more carbide is contained in catalysts promoted with K and Rb. As demonstrated by H2-TPR and the CO pulsing into He experiments, Li and Na restrain the reduction of catalysts in H2 and slightly facilitate the adsorption of CO, which results in the suppression of catalyst reduction and carburization in syngas. With the addition of K and Rb, the reduction of catalysts in H2 is continuously inhibited while the adsorption of CO is largely enhanced and becomes predominant. As a result, the catalyst reduction and carburization in syngas is slightly improved with addition of K and Rb. 3.2 Pulsing CO into a steady-state H2 flow Fig. 4 displays the CO conversion obtained during one pulse of CO into H2 flow at 533K over different catalysts. In the pure H2 flow, the un-promoted catalyst (FeSi) exhibited the highest degree of CO conversion (98%). With the addition of alkali metals, the CO conversions decrease to various degrees. The decreasing degrees over these catalysts are in the turn of LiFeSi<RbFeSi<NaFeSi<KFeSi. When CO was pulsed into a flow of 10% H2/90% He, the CO conversion was also decreased over the FeSi catalyst. It is due to the decreased H2 concentration in the pulse reaction system. Similarly, alkali metal promoters further decrease the CO conversion over the alkali-promoted catalysts compared with the pure H2 flow. These results indicate that alkali metals play the same roles as the decreased H2 concentration in inhibiting the CO conversion. The transient response curves of CH4 obtained during the hydrogenation of a CO pulse into pure H2 flow at 533K are shown in Fig. 5 . The un-promoted catalyst exhibited a sharp and narrow response curve of CH4 with the strongest intensity, which indicates a strong hydrogenation capability. Weak and long-tailing CH4 curves were observed over alkali-promoted catalysts. Since it is known that CH4 readsorbs neither on metallic iron [21,22] nor on iron carbides [3,23], the signal broadening is not due to readsorption effect. Instead, the different signal shapes are attributed to the influence of the alkali promoters. On the one hand, alkali metals suppress H2 chemisorptions [6,24], which would decrease the hydrogenation capability of surface carbon species and delay the carbon species desorption. On the other hand, alkali metals can enhance the adsorption of carbon species [24,25]. The tailing CH4 signal could also be attributed to the strongly adsorbed carbon species. To quantitatively analyze the overlapping peaks, these CH4 response curves were fitted with Gaussian curves to yield up several peaks and the corresponding peak areas are listed in Table 3 . All the CH4 signal spectra were well fitted with four peaks. As shown in Table 3, the amount of CH4 decreased remarkably with the addition of alkali metals, and gradually declined with increasing the period order of alkali metals. Meanwhile, the peak positions of all fitted peaks shifted to longer retention times with the incorporation of alkali metals. Fig. 6 illustrates the transient response curves of C2H6 obtained during the hydrogenation of a CO pulse into pure H2 flow at 533K over the different iron catalysts, and the corresponding effluent amounts are listed in Table 2. The signal shape of the C2H6 response curves was qualitatively identical and exhibited only a sharp peak for all catalysts investigated. The effluent amount of C2H6, as shown in Table 2, differed significantly over different catalysts. The addition of alkali metals markedly increased the intensity of C2H6 signal. The intensity increased in order of FeSi, LiFeSi, RbFeSi, NaFeSi and KFeSi. In the experiment, when CO pulsing into H2 flow, it undergoes adsorption, hydrogenates into surface carbon species (CH x , x =1–3) and finally desorbes as methane and a small amount of ethane. The transient CO conversion is dependent on the hydrogenation and desorption rates of surface carbon species. Decreasing H2 concentration is not favorable for the hydrogenation of surface carbon species. Thus, the transient conversion of CO in 10% H2/90% He flow is lower than that in pure H2 flow. Correspondingly, alkali metals also have similar effects on the transient CO conversion. From this point, it can be concluded that alkali metals probably decrease the surface H concentration in the turn of Li<Na<K<Rb. This is consistent with the inhibiting effect of alkali metals on H2 chemisorptions [6,24], which could be ascribed to the basicity of alkali oxide increased in the order of Li2O<Na2O<K2O<Rb2O. Alkalis are known to have strong basicity and can donate electrons to iron. The electrons donated to iron from alkalis could lead to the increase in the electronic charge of the orbitals of iron atoms. This would cause an increase in the degree of back-donating from these orbitals towards the antidonating orbitals of the chemisorbed H2 and therefore suppress the H2 adsorption [9]. Since the decreased H concentration is not favorable for the hydrogenation of surface carbon species, the CC coupling probability would increase. As a result, the CH4 formation decreases in turn of Li>Na>K>Rb, while the ethane formation increases. The results show that alkali metals decrease the transient conversion of CO in H2 atmospheres. It seems inconsistent with the conventional knowledge that alkali metals can improve CO chemisorption on iron surfaces [6,26]. In fact, it is not inconsistent because the pulse of CO in H2 is a hydrogenation but not single chemisorption process. 3.3 Pulsing CO into a steady-state He flow The pulse adsorption of CO was characterized by pulsing CO into He flow. The percentage of CO adsorption over different iron catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The FeSi catalyst showed CO adsorption of 8.8%. Clearly more CO was adsorbed over alkali-promoted catalysts. Especially, the KFeSi catalyst exhibited the highest percentage of CO adsorption (71.5%). These results revealed that the adsorption of CO was greatly improved with the addition of alkali promoters. It is consistent with literature [6,24,26,27], alkalis could donates electrons to iron and consequently facilitates CO chemisorption, since CO tends to accept electrons from iron. The stronger basicity of alkali would be more effective on enhancing CO chemisorption. In summary, the pulse experiments indicate that alkali metals decrease the surface H concentration, inhibit the hydrogenation of surface carbon species, suppress the methane formation and improve the CO adsorption and the carbon chain growth. 3.4 Steady-state FTS experiments The CO conversion and hydrocarbon selectivity of the catalysts in steady-state experiments are summarized in Table 4 . CO conversions of Li and Na promoted catalysts were slightly lower than that of the un-promoted catalyst, whereas the incorporation of K and Rb increased the catalyst activity. In the pulse experiment, alkali metals are proven to improve the CO adsorption. The enhanced CO adsorption usually leads to increased CO conversions in steady-state FTS reactions [6,7]. However, the FTS activities of iron-based catalysts are dominated by the amount of active phases. As demonstrated by H2-TPR, alkali metals usually inhibit the reduction of iron oxides in H2 and maybe decrease the reduction degree of catalysts. For Li and Na promoted catalysts, the reduction degree of catalysts decrease compared to FeSi catalyst (As evidenced by MES). As a result, the enhanced CO adsorption cannot compete with the decreased reduction degree. Therefore, it leads to a low CO conversion on LiFeSi and NaFeSi catalysts. For the product distribution, methane and C2 C4 selectivity decreased while C5 + selectivity increased over alkali-promoted catalysts, indicating that alkali metals suppressed CH4 formation and increased the chain growth probability. It is consistent with the results in the pulse experiments. In addition, the olefin/paraffin ratios (C2–4 =/C2–4) were strongly increased over alkali metal promoted catalysts. The increase in olefin selectivity can be also be explained by the suppressed hydrogenation capability of alkali metal promoted catalysts. 4 Conclusion The influence of alkali metals on the CO adsorption and hydrogenation over iron-based catalysts was investigated by pulsing CO into He or H2 flows. The main product formed during the pulse experiments was methane, and a small amount of ethane. The amount of CH4 gradually declined with increasing the periodic orders of alkali metals while the amount of ethane increased. Alkali metals significantly decreased the surface concentration of hydrogen, inhibited the hydrogenation capability, and improved the CO adsorption and CC coupling reaction with increasing the periodic orders of alkali metals. These were being ascribed to the increasing basic strength of alkali oxides in the order of Li2O<Na2O<K2O<Rb2O. The rules concluded from the pulse experiments can explain the CO hydrogenation performance under steady-state FTS conditions over the alkali metal promoted catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The CO hydrogenation reactions over un-promoted and alkali (Li, Na, K and Rb) promoted iron-based catalysts were studied by pulsing CO method. The pulse experiments indicate that alkali metals suppress the CO hydrogenation or conversion and the methane formation. Through analyzing the data, it is found that alkali promoters decrease the surface concentration of hydrogen, improve the CO adsorption and increase the retention time of carbon species on the catalyst surface in the turn of Li, Na, K, Rb. These promotional effects well explain the hydrocarbon product variation over different alkali promoted catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of alkali on iron-based catalysts for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis: CO chemisorptions study
